summary: This is a memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys in support of her third motion for release on bail. It proposes two new conditions: renouncing her French and British citizenship, and placing her and her spouse's assets under the monitoring of a retired federal judge. The document argues these conditions eliminate flight risk and criticizes the strength of the government's case.

events.title: Filing of Third Bail Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team files this memorandum in support of her third motion for release on bail, proposing new conditions.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell proposes renouncing her French and British citizenship as a condition for bail to eliminate any potential extradition protections.

Maxwell proposes placing all her and her spouse's liquid assets (except for legal fees and basic living expenses) into a new account monitored and co-signed by retired federal judge William S. Duffey, Jr.
The defense argues that twelve pretrial motions filed by January 25, 2021, raise substantial legal issues that could lead to dismissal of some or all charges, undermining the government's case.
The document states Maxwell is an American citizen who has lived in the U.S. for 30 years and has no intention to flee, seeking only to prepare for trial.
The defense compares Maxwell's case to that of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who was granted bail in New York on serious sexual assault charges despite being a foreign national.
